citations.narrative:
An excessive accumulation of feces was present in the rear corner of the ferret enclosure as well as in the in the
cardboard litter box. These accumulations are attracting flies and producing odors. While the ferrets move through the
enclosure, they are subject to coming in contact with the fecal accumulations. The feces shall be removed as often as
necessary to prevent such accumulations and odors.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: OCTOBER 23, 2023

Numerous flies were present throughout the mammal room. Fly traps are present but they are not efficiently removing
unwanted flies. Flies were observed in and on the ferret and chinchilla enclosures. Flies can spread disease and bacteria
and are not good for the health of the animals housed in the mammal room. Facility shall maintain an effective method of
pest control.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be
established and maintained.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: OCTOBER 24, 2023.

The wire enclosures, housing the various bird species, are located against the walls of the bird room. Due to the location
of the enclosures on the rear wall, the birds housed therein have access to the painted surface of the cinderblock wall.
The birds have pecked at the paint on this wall thus exposing the natural surface. This exposed surface cannot be readily
cleaned and sanitized as required. Surfaces must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the
surface or prevents cleaning.
Facility must repair this surface so that it is in good repair and capable of being cleaned and sanitized.
The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily
cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in
contact with birds must be:
Free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: NOVEMBER 17, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a written environmental enhancement plan in place for the parakeets, lovebirds, canaries, and
cockatiels present. The birds are group housed per species. Branches and perches are available for enrichment but a
written plan has not been documented. Facility must develop, document and follow a plan for bird environmental
enhancement. This plan must also be approved by the attending veterinarian. Enrichments are necessary to ensure that
the birds are provided with methods to enhance their psychological well-being.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the
attending veterinarian.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: NOVEMBER 17 ,2023
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
JESSICA GOWINS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
An excessive accumulation of feces was present in the rear corner of the ferret enclosure as well as in the in the 
cardboard litter box. These accumulations are attracting flies and producing odors. While the ferrets move through the 
enclosure, they are subject to coming in contact with the fecal accumulations. The feces shall be removed as often as 
necessary to prevent such accumulations and odors. 
 
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals 
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: OCTOBER 23, 2023 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Numerous flies were present throughout the mammal room. Fly traps are present but they are not efficiently removing 
unwanted flies. Flies were observed in and on the ferret and chinchilla enclosures. Flies can spread disease and bacteria 
and are not good for the health of the animals housed in the mammal room. Facility shall maintain an effective method of 
pest control. 
 
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be 
established and maintained. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: OCTOBER 24, 2023. 
3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The wire enclosures, housing the various bird species, are located against the walls of the bird room. Due to the location 
of the enclosures on the rear wall, the birds housed therein have access to the painted surface of the cinderblock wall. 
The birds have pecked at the paint on this wall thus exposing the natural surface. This exposed surface cannot be readily 
cleaned and sanitized as required. Surfaces must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the

surface or prevents cleaning. 
 
Facility must repair this surface so that it is in good repair and capable of being cleaned and sanitized. 
 
The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily 
cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in 
contact with birds must be:  
 
Free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: NOVEMBER 17, 2023 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not have a written environmental enhancement plan in place for the parakeets, lovebirds, canaries, and 
cockatiels present. The birds are group housed per species. Branches and perches are available for enrichment but a 
written plan has not been documented. Facility must develop, document and follow a plan for bird environmental 
enhancement. This plan must also be approved by the attending veterinarian. Enrichments are necessary to ensure that 
the birds are provided with methods to enhance their psychological well-being. 
 
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for 
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the 
attending veterinarian. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: NOVEMBER 17 ,2023 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors:
